articles.title: Trump removes video with racist clip depicting Obamas as apes
articles.body: Before it was removed, Derrick Johnson, the president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, or NAACP, called the video "disgusting and utterly despicable" and accused Trump of attempting to distract the public from the Epstein case and a "rapidly failing economy."

articles.title: Trump signs executive order threatening tariffs for countries trading with Iran
articles.body: It read: "The President is holding Iran accountable for its pursuit of nuclear capabilities, support for terrorism, ballistic missile development, and regional destabilization that endanger American security, allies, and interests."

articles.title: Winter Olympics 2026 opening ceremony: Milan-Cortina Games open as Mariah Carey & Andrea Bocelli perform - BBC Sport
articles.body:
Before the parade, creative director Marco Balich's show was based around the principle of 'armonia' - meaning union, connection, agreement - with "a narrative aimed at uniting territories, people and values within a shared vision".

It featured sections labelled 'Italian beauty' and 'fantasia', with a tribute to fashion designer Giorgio Armani, who died aged 91 in 2025.

Meanwhile, American singer Mariah Carey - one of the world's best-selling female artists - was decked out in a sparkling white outfit as she performed a version of Volare.

"We stand ready to make Olympic history again, inspired by the values that unite all of us: excellence, friendship and respect," said Giovanni Malago, president of the organising committee for Milan-Cortina 2026.

"The co-ordination of so many different bodies in the pursuit of one dream has been a powerful expression of this country's ability to deliver such a complex project.

"I have never been as proud to be Italian as I am tonight."

It was left to International Olympic Committee president Kirsty Coventry to declare the Games open.

As the first female IOC president, it is the first time the Olympics have been officially opened by a woman.

"This is why we all love the Games. Because through you, we see the very best of ourselves," she told the athletes.

"You remind us that we can be brave. That we can be kind. That we can get back up, no matter how hard we fall.

"The spirit of the Olympic Games is about so much more than sport. It is about us - and what makes us human.

"This is the magic of the Olympic Games: inspiring us all to be the best that we can be, together."

While events such as curling, figure skating and ice hockey have already begun, the first five gold medals of the Games will be won on Saturday.

articles.title: Will Sunday's snap election gamble pay off for Japan's first female premier?
articles.body: Other long-held priorities have also faded from her campaign, including weapons exports, an anti-espionage law and immigration reform. This tactic, observers say, is less about policy and more about keeping her high position in the polls.

articles.title: Bad Bunny has the Super Bowl stage. What will he do with it?
articles.body: Bad Bunny has said he feels a responsibility, as someone with influence, to highlight important issues. He has consistently used his platform and music to not only showcase his culture, but support the LGBTQ community and advocate for Puerto Rico's self-determination, which has remained an overseas US territory since 1898.

articles.title: Gazans returning through Rafah crossing describe checks by Palestinian militia
articles.body: "They took perfumes, accessories, make-up, cigarettes, headphones - everything, they didn't leave anything with us," one woman told the BBC.

articles.title: Police probe new message in search for mother of Savannah Guthrie
articles.body: At a briefing on Thursday, FBI Special Agent Heith Janke said his agency was reviewing one of the notes, which he called a possible ransom note. It gave a deadline for payment of 17:00 on Thursday, he said, without specifying which time zone, and had a second deadline for Monday.

articles.title: US intervention in Iran: What Iranians inside and outside the country say
articles.body: "I don't know how many have been killed, how many are injured, or who is missing. I don't know how to reach mothers, fathers, brothers, sisters, wives, husbands, or children to offer condolences and express solidarity," he said.

articles.title: Talks with US set to continue after 'good beginning', Iran's foreign minister says
articles.body: The Human Rights Activists News Agency, a Washington-based group, said it had confirmed at least 6,941 deaths, warning the number could be much higher, and that more than 50,000 people had been arrested.

articles.title: Russian general Alexeyev shot several times in Moscow attack
articles.body: In December 2025, another high-ranking officer in the GRU, Lt Gen Fanil Sarvarov, was killed when an explosive device detonated under a car in Moscow. He was in charge of the armed force's operational training department, according to Russia's SK.

articles.title: Zambia fisherman fleeing elephants killed by crocodile
articles.body: Of the 26 wildlife-related deaths recorded in 2023, 15 were caused by crocodile attacks, most of them along the Luangwa River, according to Resource Africa, a community-led conservation NGO.

articles.title: Queen Elizabeth II: Coin portrait of late monarch criticised in Australia
articles.body: These include motifs of a horse and corgi, references to art and theatre to mark "her enduring support for culture", as well as some of her favourite flowers - roses and lily of the valley. The golden wattle, Australia's national floral emblem, is also represented.

articles.title: Suspected Chinese spies arrested in quiet French town
articles.body: According to the prosecutor's office, the suspected spies were trying to "capture satellite data from [X owner Elon Musk's] Starlink network, as well as data from vital entities, notably military, in order to retransmit them to their country of origin, China".

articles.title: Nigerian court orders UK to pay £420m over 1949 killing of miners in Iva Valley, Enugu
articles.body: "This ruling represents a significant milestone in the pursuit of historical accountability and justice for colonial-era violations, affirming that the right to life transcends time, borders, and changes in sovereignty," said the applicants' lawyer, Prof Yemi Akinseye-George.

articles.title: TikTok told by EU to change 'addictive design' or face fines
articles.body: In its preliminary findings, the Commission said TikTok did not "adequately assess" how features like autoplay could harm the wellbeing of its users, including children, and said it failed to implement measures to mitigate the risks.

articles.title: Ukrainian mother's joy after phone call with son she thought had been killed
articles.body: "It was so strange, because my son had died, I buried him, but here's his voice. Can you imagine the emotions of a mother? Happiness. Great happiness. I could not hold back my tears," Nataliya said.

articles.title: Norway's crown princess apologises after pressure over Epstein friendship
articles.body: If found guilty by the three judges at Oslo district court, he could face a jail term of at least 10 years. Two days before the trial began, he was arrested for a fourth time on Sunday, on suspicion of assault, wielding a knife and violating a restraining order.

articles.title: Pakistan mosque explosion: More than 30 dead and 169 injured, officials say
articles.body: Amaq alleged that the IS attacker arrived at the "central temple [mosque]" in Tarlai district in the Shahzad area. Guards at the location then tried to halt the attacker at the external gate, it claimed, but he fired his pistol at them, injuring two, before heading inside.

articles.title: FBI fugitive found hiding in north Wales set for extradited to USA

Lønseth, head of Økokrim - the economic crime unit investigating Jagland - said: "We consider there are reasonable grounds for investigation, given that he held the positions of chair of the Nobel Committee and Secretary General of the Council of Europe during the period covered by the released documents.

articles.title: 'I dreamed of becoming a K-pop idol - but I felt like I was scammed'
articles.body: The company, however, denied that the staff member entered the female dormitory, and said the cameras were installed only in common areas, such as entrances and kitchens, for "safety reasons", following past incidents involving intruders.

articles.title: What we still don't know about the disappearance of Savannah Guthrie's mother
articles.body:
Nearly a week since the disappearance of Nancy Guthrie, the mother of US news presenter Savannah Guthrie, police are investigating a new message sent to a local news station. It comes after the first deadline from an alleged ransom letter passed on Thursday evening.

Guthrie's family continues to plea for proof that their mother, who is believed to have been abducted from her home in Tucson, Arizona, is still alive.

The BBC's Regan Morris is in Tucson and details the status of the investigation, and the questions that remain.

articles.title: Anke Gowda: The Karnataka man who built a library of two million books
articles.body: The place is frequented by students, their parents, teachers and book lovers. Regular visitors seem to know their way around the library and find the books they need with ease. And even if they can't, they say, Gowda can find anything.

articles.title: Kwara attack survivors in Nigeria: 'They sent a letter asking to preach. Then they massacred us'
articles.body: "They came en masse in the name of religion, and they decided to kill our people," Abdulla Umar Usman, a former teacher and resident of Woro, told the BBC, explaining how the attack, in which at least 75 people are so far known to have been killed, unfolded.

articles.title: Watch: Trump has called to nationalise US elections. Is it a big deal?
articles.body:
US President Donald Trump has urged Republicans to "nationalise" elections while repeating his false claims of 2020 election fraud in a podcast interview.

The US Constitution says that individual states determine how they carry out elections, and voting has long been administered by local officials across the country.

The BBC's Washington correspondent Daniel Bush explains why the president's comments are causing a stir in a midterm election year.

Video edited by Alex Foster, filmed by Blanca Estrada

articles.title: We had sex in a Chinese hotel, then found we had been broadcast to thousands
articles.body: What is clear is there are significant sums of money to be made. Based on channel membership and subscription fees, the BBC estimates AKA alone has earned at least 163,200 Yuan ($22,000, £16,300) since last April. The average annual income in China last year was 43,377 Yuan ($6,200, £4,600) according to China's Bureau of Statistics.

articles.title: US-South Africa funding: As American cash dries up the fight to stop Aids gets harder
articles.body: "I often say to people, in order to end the epidemic for the world, we really do need to end the epidemic in South Africa. If we do not contain it, close it down, shut it down, we stand the huge risk of it continuing for decades."

articles.title: Watch: Ukrainian soldier thought to be dead calls his family
articles.body:
This is the moment Nazar Daletskyi’s family found out that their relative, who was thought to have died fighting as a Ukrainian soldier in the first year of Russia’s full-scale invasion, was in fact alive.

They were told he had died in September 2022 and a few months later they received a body that they believed was his and buried him in their home region of Lviv in western Ukraine.

A few months ago, some of his fellow soldiers told his mother Nataliya they thought he was alive and on Thursday he was released as part of a prisoner exchange of soldiers and civilians between Ukraine and Russia.

articles.title: What the Super Bowl means to American fans
articles.body: <html><body></body></html>

articles.title: Watch: The US and Russia's nuclear treaty is dead. What comes next?
articles.body:
The New START Treaty, initially signed by the United States and Russia in 2010, continued a string of nuclear arms control agreements between the two countries stretching back to 1991.

But on 5 February 2026 it expired – leaving no limit on the number of nuclear weapons the US and Russia can stockpile.

The BBC's Washington correspondent Daniel Bush explains what comes next for nuclear weapons in the 21st century.

Video edited by Alex Foster

articles.title: Watch: What's happened since Savannah Guthrie's mother disappeared?
articles.body:
Arizona police say they believe Nancy Guthrie, the missing mother of US news anchor Savannah Guthrie, "is still out there", after she disappeared from her home this weekend. Police say they have yet to identify a suspect in her disappearance.

At a media briefing on Thursday, Pima County Sheriff Chris Nanos said investigators are working under the assumption she is still alive and are "going to continue thinking that way until we find her".

Here's what has happened since the 84-year-old grandmother was reported missing on Sunday.

articles.title: Inside Gaza hospital struggling to provide care to newborn babies
articles.body:
The director of one of Gaza's main hospitals says he is still seeing a pattern of malnourished and traumatised mothers giving birth to underweight or premature babies, more than three months into a fragile ceasefire between Hamas and Israel.

Although significantly more aid has been allowed into Gaza since the ceasefire began, the UN says it is still nowhere near enough.

Israel says it is meeting its obligations under the ceasefire, allowing more food and medical aid into Gaza.

Shaimaa Khalil reports.
